title: Potential Energy - compare energies of springs

content.description:
Spring <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is attached at one end to a wall and at the other end to a block of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. The block is displaced a distance <math alttext="d sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the equilibrium position of the block-Spring <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> system, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"> <mn>1</mn> </math>. With the block a distance <math alttext="d sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from equilibrium, the potential energy of the system is <math alttext="U sub A comma 1, end sub" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>U</mi> <mtext>A,1</mtext> </msub> </math>.

An identical spring, Spring <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, is also attached to a wall and a block of mass \(M\). The block is displaced a distance <math alttext="2 d sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the equilibrium position of the block-Spring <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> system, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. With the block a distance <math alttext="2 d sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from equilibrium, the potential energy of the system is <math alttext="U sub B comma 1, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,1</mtext></msub></math>.

The blocks are returned to their equilibrium positions, and the potential energy of the block-Spring <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> system and the potential energy of the block-Spring <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> system are <math alttext="U sub A comma 2, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,2</mtext></msub></math>Â and <math alttext="U sub B comma 2, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,2</mtext></msub></math>, respectively.
content.question:
Which of the following correctly compares the potential energy of the systems at maximum displacement from equilibrium and the potential energy of the systems at their equilibrium positions.

Potential Energy at Maximum Displacement from Equilibrium
 Potential Energy at Equilibrium

A
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 1, end sub, is greater than U sub B comma 1, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,1</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,1</mtext></msub></math>
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 2, end sub, equals U sub B comma 2, end sub" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>U</mi> <mtext>A,2</mtext> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mi>U</mi> <mtext>B,2</mtext> </msub> </math>

B
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 1, end sub, is greater than U sub B comma 1, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,1</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,1</mtext></msub></math>
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 2, end sub, is less than U sub B comma 2, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,2</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,2</mtext></msub></math>

C
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 1, end sub, is less than U sub B comma 1, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,1</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,1</mtext></msub></math>
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 2, end sub, equals U sub B comma 2, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,2</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,2</mtext></msub></math>

D
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 1, end sub, is less than U sub B comma 1, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,1</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,1</mtext></msub></math>
 <math alttext="U sub A comma 2, end sub, is less than U sub B comma 2, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>A,2</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>B,2</mtext></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
